mechanoreception.notes: As sponges, Leucettidae likely possess mechanoreceptors to detect water flow and physical stimuli. This is inferred from the general physiology of sponges which rely on water flow for feeding and gas exchange.

chemoreception.notes: Leucettidae likely use chemoreception to detect food particles and other chemical cues in the water. This is inferred from the general physiology of sponges, which are filter feeders.

photoreception.notes: The presence of photoreceptors is unknown in Leucettidae. There is no indication of specialized light-sensing organs in the provided context.
